summary: I like the people who hate Brie and who claim she’s destroying Marvel/she single handedly ruined Endgame (like these are things...
body:
I like the people who hate Brie and who claim she’s destroying Marvel/she single handedly ruined Endgame (like these are things people have legit said).

I mean, man do I stan myself one powerful lady! XD Marvel has been building for over twenty films and has a massive cast of various famous actors, yet Brie is apparently enough to bring the whole thing down just by existing! Same for her ruining Endgame. She’s got the shortest amount of screen time in it and yet apparently that is enough to ruin the whole film!

Gotta love one powerful lady.

blog.description: Batman, Say it fast. Really fast. As fast as you can. Over and over. So what do you hear? Badman. Bad. Man. Batman. Badman. To me... Now and forever... one and                                             the same. - Peter J. Tomasi                                                                         all spoiler posts are tagged "wednesday spoilers"                                             add me on snapchapt! taskrnaster (with an RN instead of M)

blog.name: herculesinegypt
blog.title: cheesecake
blog.description: man i'm just trying to write some fic /requests: open

title: Pretty Brown Eyes
body:
There was something about Carol Danvers that mesmerized you. No matter what she did you found it so fascinating, you couldn’t help but feel attracted to her. She made your mind throb and your heart go 100 miles per hour whenever she was around. It drove you so crazy, that you finally decided to confess your feelings to her. One evening, the two of you found yourselves in a dimly lit bar having drinks and enjoying yourselves. After awhile you couldn’t help it, the woman was just too damn gorgeous and you were too damn drunk. “I love you” was all your mouth allowed you to say. It was simple but it meant so much. Carol looked up from her glass with a playful glint in her eyes until she saw your serious ones staring back at her. 

“Y/N…..I don’t know….”

She was flustered, probably more than you. “I can’t. I have a lot of things I need to take care of and I….I just don’t want to do that right now. I’m sorry.”

You looked down to the ground in defeat and embarrassment. What did you expect to happen? A miracle? For her to say those precious words right back to you? Carol sighed, knowing exactly what you might be thinking.

“But I don’t want to lose you either, you’re a good friend to me.”

You looked at her stoically and said nothing. Drinking your sorrows away seemed like the main event for the rest of the night. Not wanting to bother you or upset you anymore, Carol patted your back and walked out.

———————————————–

At first, the atmosphere around you two was very tense and awkward. It was only after a couple of weeks when things started turning back to normal. You had seen her earlier but didn’t have the strength to talk to her until now. You approached her and after a heavy sigh you looked up at her.

“I’m sorry”

“You don’t have anything to be sorry for, I shouldn’t have just left like tha-”

You cut her off and flashed a bright smile, “Carol, I miss hanging out with you”

Seeing your smile made Carol’s heart jump. After that the two of you were inseparable and spent the whole afternoon talking about activities to do together in the evening. Eventually, the two of you decided to have a horror movie marathon at your house. But for Carol, the night was not a fond one for her. She couldn’t stop staring or thinking about you. You could tell her head was somewhere else. Touching her shoulder, you attempted to break her out of her daze.

“Carol are you okay?” You mentioned with a worried look on your face.

Avoiding your question, she instead pulled into a kiss. Not wasting a moment, you returned the passion. When the two of you broke away, she couldn’t help but stare at you. Her eyes filled with love you never thought she had for you. Considering the way Carol was looking at you, she wasn’t satisfied with just a kiss but you were more than happy to oblige to whatever she wanted for the rest of the night. 

—————————————————-

To say you were frustrated was an understatement, you were infuriated. You and Carol had an amazing night together. It was more than amazing, it was ethereal. But for some reason, Ms. Danvers has been avoiding you like the plague and making up any excuse not to be around you. It was driving you insane, but more importantly, your heart was breaking into a million piece. Does she even like you? Was it just sex? You honestly had enough of her behavior. You marched into the headquarters, intent on finding Carol. Unbeknownst to you, Carol was going through her own dilemma as well. Not knowing whether to be with you or not. To be honest, Carol is in love with you, but she didn’t want to hurt you or herself. Of course, she wanted to be happy with you, but what if she couldn’t? What if your action packed lives couldn’t handle a relationship? She found herself walking aimlessly with nothing but conflicting thoughts racing in her head. She stopped dead in her tracks when she saw a pair of shoes a few feet from her. Her brown eyes scanning your body, eventually stopping at your face. A sense of guilt washing over her as she noticed your pained expression. In a matter seconds, you moved towards her. Now standing face to face, you looked at her with a stern look in your eyes.

“I just want to know one thing. Will you be with me?

There was something about Carol Danvers that mesmerized you. No matter what she did you found it so fascinating, you couldn’t help but feel attracted to her. Carol looked up from her glass with a playful glint in her eyes until she saw your serious ones staring back at her. 

“Y/N…..I don’t know….”

tags: try and grow out of it
or at least learn to shut up.
summary: Reminder to the Trollboys out there that no one takes you seriously when it comes to your hate on Captain Marvel because of how...
body:
Reminder to the Trollboys out there that no one takes you seriously when it comes to your hate on Captain Marvel because of how pathetic most of your arguments are.

Also, Brie Larson is so much better than you people - and that’s without her even trying to be. Then again, it really isn’t all that hard to be better than you.

reblog.comment:
Reminder to the Trollboys out there that no one takes you seriously when it comes to your hate on Captain Marvel because of how pathetic most of your arguments are.

Also, Brie Larson is so much better than you people - and that’s without her even trying to be. Then again, it really isn’t all that hard to be better than you.

trail.content_raw:
Reminder to the Trollboys out there that no one takes you seriously when it comes to your hate on Captain Marvel because of how pathetic most of your arguments are.

Also, Brie Larson is so much better than you people - and that’s without her even trying to be. Then again, it really isn’t all that hard to be better than you.

summary: How That Extra Two Minutes Went Down In The Marvel Writer Room
title: How That Extra Two Minutes Went Down In The Marvel Writer Room
body:
Russo Brothers: There all done.
Writers: Good lets film it
*Films movie*
Russo Brothers: Aw shit we forgot to add this two minutes in the ending!
Writers: Ah man!
Russo Brothers: Let's wait until it gets released and wait a few months, let's say june then we come at the fans and say on Twitter, 'Hey btw we are releasing Endgame for two extra minutes!'
Writers and Russo Brothers: *High Five*

summary: I work in a Target as a phone specialist, so I’m in the electronics department all day, listening to the same music spots and...
body:
I work in a Target as a phone specialist, so I’m in the electronics department all day, listening to the same music spots and movie ads over and over again on both the TV wall AND a billboard-like preview screen above the book section. So this stuff gets old very quickly. Even the bits I like, it’s not so much I “enjoy” them as it is I don’t want to actively claw my eyes out when they play. Even the different Captain Marvel spots are little more than a couple minutes of zero irritation floating at the back of my mind.

Until earlier this week, when a tiny boy that couldn’t have been older than a year and a half, maybe two years old, noticed the Captain Marvel movie/companion book ad on the big screen. His eyes lit up and he punched his fist into the air in his best superhero pose, giving a little “raahhh!” as he tried to copy the moves Carol was doing onscreen. This went on for the duration of the ad, this little boy hopping around and waving his arms like he was fighting off bad guys, like I’ve seen other kids do when they see Superman or Spider-Man. I was grinning like an idiot the entire time.

And even later, a woman came up to buy something from the desk with her son in the basket of her cart, probably seven or eight years old. She began her transaction as the same CM spot came on, and the boy twisted around to watch it, chanting “Cap-tain Mar-vel! Cap-tain Mar-vel!”, something that would have been super irritating if I wasn’t so over-the-moon about not one but two little boys outwardly adoring this badass superhero. It didn’t matter to them that she was a woman - she’s strong and fast and has laser fists and is awesome, just like all the other superheroes that they love. It’s so refreshing to see young boys idolizing an incredible woman, and it’s a sight I will never take for granted.

I work in a Target as a phone specialist, so I’m in the electronics department all day, listening to the same music spots and movie ads over and over again on both the TV wall AND a billboard-like preview screen above the book section. So this stuff gets old very quickly. Even the bits I like, it’s not so much I “enjoy” them as it is I don’t want to actively claw my eyes out when they play. Even the different Captain Marvel spots are little more than a couple minutes of zero irritation floating at the back of my mind.

Until earlier this week, when a tiny boy that couldn’t have been older than a year and a half, maybe two years old, noticed the Captain Marvel movie/companion book ad on the big screen. His eyes lit up and he punched his fist into the air in his best superhero pose, giving a little “raahhh!” as he tried to copy the moves Carol was doing onscreen. This went on for the duration of the ad, this little boy hopping around and waving his arms like he was fighting off bad guys, like I’ve seen other kids do when they see Superman or Spider-Man. I was grinning like an idiot the entire time.

And even later, a woman came up to buy something from the desk with her son in the basket of her cart, probably seven or eight years old. She began her transaction as the same CM spot came on, and the boy twisted around to watch it, chanting “Cap-tain Mar-vel! Cap-tain Mar-vel!”, something that would have been super irritating if I wasn’t so over-the-moon about not one but two little boys outwardly adoring this badass superhero. It didn’t matter to them that she was a woman - she’s strong and fast and has laser fists and is awesome, just like all the other superheroes that they love. It’s so refreshing to see young boys idolizing an incredible woman, and it’s a sight I will never take for granted.
